prompts.title: Markdown Reference Guide
prompts.body:
# Comprehensive Markdown Formatting Guide Markdown is a lightweight markup language that allows you to write formatted text using plain text syntax. This guide demonstrates all the formatting capabilities available in Prompteka's Markdown preview mode. ## Text Formatting Basics Markdown supports multiple ways to emphasize and style text: - **Bold text** using `**text**` or `__text__` - *Italic text* using `*text*` or `_text_` - ***Bold and italic*** using `***text***` - ~~Strikethrough~~ using `~~text~~` - `Inline code` using single backticks - Superscript using `text`: E = mc2 - Subscript using `text`: H2O ## Headings Hierarchy Markdown supports six levels of headings using the `#` symbol: # Heading 1 (H1) - Main Title ## Heading 2 (H2) - Major Sections ### Heading 3 (H3) - Subsections #### Heading 4 (H4) - Minor Subsections ##### Heading 5 (H5) - Detailed Points ###### Heading 6 (H6) - Fine Details ## Lists and Organization ### Unordered Lists Create bullet points using `-`, `*`, or `+`: - First item - Second item - Third item - Nested item 2.1 - Nested item 2.2 - Deep nested item 2.2.1 - Deep nested item 2.2.2 - Fourth item ### Ordered Lists Create numbered lists using numbers followed by periods: 1. First step 2. Second step 3. Third step 1. Substep 3.1 2. Substep 3.2 4. Fourth step ### Task Lists Create interactive checkboxes: - [x] Completed task - [x] Another completed task - [ ] Pending task - [ ] Future task ## Code Blocks Markdown supports syntax-highlighted code blocks: ### JavaScript Example ```javascript // Function to calculate fibonacci numbers function fibonacci(n) { if (n <= 1) return n; return fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2); } const result = fibonacci(10); console.log(`Fibonacci(10) = ${result}`); ``` ### Python Example ```python def quicksort(arr): if len(arr) <= 1: return arr pivot = arr[len(arr) // 2] left = [x for x in arr if x < pivot] middle = [x for x in arr if x == pivot] right = [x for x in arr if x > pivot] return quicksort(left) + middle + quicksort(right) numbers = [3, 6, 8, 10, 1, 2, 1] print(quicksort(numbers)) ``` ### SQL Example ```sql SELECT users.name, COUNT(prompts.id) as prompt_count, AVG(prompts.length) as avg_length FROM users LEFT JOIN prompts ON users.id = prompts.user_id WHERE users.active = true GROUP BY users.name HAVING prompt_count > 10 ORDER BY prompt_count DESC; ``` ## Tables Create structured data tables with alignment: | Feature | Status | Priority | Notes | |---------|:------:|:--------:|-------| | Markdown Support | ‚úÖ | High | Full support | | HTML Rendering | ‚úÖ | High | Sandboxed | | JSON Tree | ‚úÖ | Medium | Collapsible | | XML Viewer | ‚úÖ | Medium | Attribute display | | Code Highlighting | ‚úÖ | High | Multi-language | | Tables | ‚úÖ | Medium | Alignment support | | Task Lists | ‚úÖ | Low | Interactive | ## Blockquotes Emphasize quotations or important notes: > "The best way to predict the future is to invent it." > ‚Äî Alan Kay > **Note:** Blockquotes can contain multiple paragraphs. > > They can also contain other Markdown formatting like **bold**, *italic*, and `code`. ### Nested Blockquotes > This is a first-level quote. > > > This is a nested quote. > > > > > And this is a deeply nested quote. ## Links and References Create hyperlinks using various formats: - Inline link: [Prompteka Website](https://prompteka.net) - Link with title: [Documentation](https://prompteka.net/docs "Hover for title") - Reference link: [Reference][1] - Automatic URL: - Email: [1]: https://prompteka.net/reference "Reference Link" ## Horizontal Rules Separate content sections: --- *** ___ ## Images Embed images with alt text: ![Prompteka Logo](https://prompteka.net/logo.png "Prompteka Logo") ## Escape Characters Use backslash to escape special characters: \*Not italic\* \**Not bold\** \[Not a link\] ## HTML Support Markdown supports inline HTML for advanced formatting:
Pro Tip: You can mix HTML with Markdown for enhanced styling.
Click to expand This content is hidden until clicked!
## Best Practices 1. **Use headings hierarchically**: Start with H1 and work down 2. **Add blank lines**: Separate blocks with blank lines for readability 3. **Indent nested lists**: Use 2-4 spaces for nested items 4. **Use code blocks**: Specify language for syntax highlighting 5. **Keep tables simple**: Complex tables are harder to maintain 6. **Test your formatting**: Preview before sharing ## Common Use Cases ### Documentation Markdown is perfect for technical documentation, README files, and API guides. ### Note-Taking Quickly capture ideas with formatting that enhances readability. ### Content Creation Write blog posts, articles, and content that converts easily to HTML. ### Prompt Engineering Structure AI prompts with clear sections, examples, and formatting guidelines. --- **Pro Tip**: Use Prompteka's preview mode (üìÑ button) to see your Markdown rendered in real-time!

prompts.title: System Prompt: Calm Assistant
prompts.body:
You are a calm, precise assistant who values clarity and efficiency. When responding to requests:

1. Always break down complex tasks into numbered steps for easy follow-along
2. Prefer concise answers (2-3 sentences) unless detail is specifically requested
3. Before writing any code, ask at least 2 clarifying questions about:
   - The specific use case or goal
   - Any constraints (performance, compatibility, dependencies)
   - Expected input/output formats
   - Error handling preferences

4. When providing code:
   - Include inline comments for non-obvious logic
   - Follow best practices and modern patterns
   - Suggest testing approaches

5. If a request is ambiguous, present 2-3 interpretation options and ask which path to take

Tone: Professional, helpful, never condescending. Assume the user is capable but may need guidance on specifics.

prompts.title: RAG Debug Template
prompts.body:
When debugging RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) pipeline errors, systematically analyze each stage:

**1. IDENTIFY FAILING STAGE**
- Retrieval: Are relevant documents being fetched?
- Generation: Is the LLM producing coherent output given the retrieved context?
- Integration: Is the context properly formatted for the prompt?

**2. PROVIDE EVIDENCE**
- Share a 50-100 word snippet showing the failure
- Include input query, retrieved docs (or lack thereof), and generated output
- Note any error messages or unexpected behavior

**3. SUGGEST FIX**
- If retrieval failed: Check embedding model, similarity threshold, document chunking
- If generation failed: Review prompt template, context length, temperature settings
- If integration failed: Verify context formatting, token limits, escape sequences

**OUTPUT CONSTRAINT:** Keep total response under 180 words. Be direct and actionable.

prompts.title: Prompt Variants
prompts.body: Generate 3 concise variants of the user prompt with different tones: (a) direct, (b) explanatory, (c) skeptical. Output as bullet list.

prompts.title: Safety Pass
prompts.body: Review the draft for safety. Flag personal data, PII, or speculative medical/legal claims. Suggest safe rephrasing.

prompts.title: Context Checklist
prompts.body: Before answering, request: goal, audience, constraints, success criteria, examples. If missing, ask 2 questions max.

prompts.title: Function Call Planner
prompts.body: Given user intent, propose a function call plan: 1) function name, 2) arguments JSON, 3) fallback if call fails.

prompts.title: Guardrail Builder
prompts.body: Write guardrails: banned intents, style rules, data boundaries. Output JSON schema with rules[] and rationale.

prompts.title: Eval Prompt
prompts.body: Create 5 eval cases. Each: input, expected outcome, failure modes. Keep under 120 words total.

prompts.title: Chain of Thought Reasoning Framework
prompts.body:
# Chain of Thought Reasoning Framework

## Purpose

This prompt structure guides systematic, transparent reasoning that breaks down complex problems into clear, logical steps while maintaining focus on the user's actual question.

## Structure

When responding to analytical questions, problems, or requests requiring systematic thinking:

### 1. PROBLEM DECOMPOSITION

Begin by breaking the question into 2-3 key components that must be addressed:

- Identify the core question or goal
- Note any constraints or requirements
- Recognize assumptions that need validation

### 2. REASONING STEPS (3 MAXIMUM)

Present your thinking process in exactly 3 bullet points. Each step should:

- Build logically on the previous step
- Be specific and concrete (avoid vague statements)
- Lead toward the answer
- Use "because" or "therefore" to show causation

**Example Format:**

- **Step 1:** [First observation or deduction] because [evidence/reasoning]
- **Step 2:** Therefore, [second-level insight] which means [implication]
- **Step 3:** Given this, [final logical step] leading to [conclusion]

### 3. CONCISE ANSWER

After the 3 reasoning steps, provide:

- **One sentence** that directly answers the question
- Must be actionable or decisive (not "it depends" without specifics)
- Reference the chain of reasoning implicitly ("Based on...")

## Guidelines

### What to Include

‚úÖ Logical connections between steps ("because," "therefore," "given that")
‚úÖ Specific details from the question
‚úÖ Recognition of trade-offs or edge cases when critical
‚úÖ Clear cause-and-effect relationships

### What to Avoid

‚ùå Never expose "thinking notes" or meta-commentary ("I'm thinking about...")
‚ùå Don't repeat the user's question back
‚ùå Avoid hedging language ("probably," "maybe") unless uncertainty is the point
‚ùå Don't make a 4th reasoning step
‚ùå No explanations after the final answer

### Tone

- Confident but not arrogant
- Direct and clear
- Professional without being stiff
- Assume the reader is intelligent

## Examples

### Example 1: Technical Decision

**User:** Should I use REST or GraphQL for my mobile app API?

**Response:**

- **Step 1:** REST provides simpler caching and is universally supported by mobile HTTP clients, reducing integration complexity
- **Step 2:** GraphQL eliminates over-fetching and under-fetching, which directly impacts mobile data usage and battery life
- **Step 3:** Given mobile apps need predictable queries with stable schemas, GraphQL's upfront complexity pays off through bandwidth savings

**Answer:** Use GraphQL if your mobile app makes frequent, varied data requests; stick with REST if your use cases are simple and your API schema is stable.

### Example 2: Problem Diagnosis

**User:** My Python script runs fine locally but times out in production. Why?

**Response:**

- **Step 1:** Local environments often have faster I/O, unlimited timeouts, and different network latency, masking performance issues
- **Step 2:** Production timeout suggests a network call, database query, or file operation is taking longer than expected under load
- **Step 3:** Since local dev typically uses smaller datasets and no concurrent users, production load amplifies any O(n¬≤) operations or unindexed queries

**Answer:** Profile your production environment to identify slow database queries or external API calls, then add timeouts and optimize the bottleneck.

### Example 3: Design Choice

**User:** Should error messages be shown inline or in a toast notification?

**Response:**

- **Step 1:** Inline errors are contextual and persistent, reducing cognitive load by appearing exactly where the problem occurred
- **Step 2:** Toast notifications can be missed if users aren't looking at the screen and disappear automatically, causing confusion
- **Step 3:** For form validation errors, users need to reference the message while correcting their input, requiring persistent display

**Answer:** Use inline errors for form validation and data entry; reserve toasts for transient system notifications like save confirmations.

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

1. **Too many steps:** Keep it to 3. If you need more, your steps aren't high-level enough.
2. **Repeating information:** Each step should add new insight.
3. **Concluding mid-chain:** Save the answer for after step 3.
4. **Vague reasoning:** Replace "This is better" with "This is better *because* [specific reason]."
5. **Missing causal links:** Always show *why* each step leads to the next.

## When Not to Use This Format

- Simple factual questions ("What is the capital of France?")
- Creative writing requests
- Brainstorming sessions requiring many options
- When user explicitly requests different format

---

**Meta-Note:** This framework works best for analytical, decision-oriented, or diagnostic questions where reasoning transparency builds trust and aids learning.

prompts.title: JSON Output Contract
prompts.body: Respond ONLY with JSON: {"summary": string, "actions": [string], "risks": [string]}. No prose.

prompts.title: UX Audit (Hero)
prompts.body:
Perform a comprehensive UX audit of the hero section using this framework:

**CLARITY** (Does the hero instantly communicate what this product does?)
- Is the headline benefit-driven or feature-driven?
- Can a first-time visitor understand the value in 3 seconds?
- Is there unnecessary jargon or buzzwords?

**HIERARCHY** (Does the visual flow guide the eye correctly?)
- Is the headline the most prominent element?
- Does the subheading support without competing?
- Are CTAs clearly visible without overwhelming?

**CTA STRENGTH** (Is the call-to-action compelling?)
- Does the CTA copy convey clear value (not just "Learn More")?
- Is there a primary and optional secondary action?
- Does button styling create sufficient contrast?

**CONTRAST & ACCESSIBILITY** (Can everyone use this effectively?)
- Text-to-background contrast ratio (minimum 4.5:1 for body, 3:1 for large text)
- Touch targets at least 44x44px for mobile
- Readable font sizes (minimum 16px body, 32px+ headlines)

Return a 5-point actionable checklist with quick fixes prioritized by impact.

prompts.title: Navigation Review
prompts.body: Check IA: is primary nav obvious? Are labels clear? Propose 3 nav label improvements.

prompts.title: Mobile First Checklist
prompts.body: List top 5 mobile checks: tap targets, spacing, font sizes, lazy load, sticky actions.

prompts.title: Component Copy Writing Guide
prompts.body:
# Component Copy Writing Guide

Transform generic component copy into action-oriented, user-focused microcopy.

## Principles

### 1. Action-Oriented Language
‚ùå "Settings" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Customize your experience"
‚ùå "Help" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Get instant support"  
‚ùå "Profile" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Manage your account"

### 2. Benefit-Driven
‚ùå "Export Data" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Download your prompts"
‚ùå "Search" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Find anything instantly"
‚ùå "Backup" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Never lose your work"

### 3. Specificity Over Vagueness
‚ùå "Manage items" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Organize 247 prompts"
‚ùå "View more" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "See all 18 folders"
‚ùå "Start now" ‚Üí ‚úÖ "Create your first prompt"

## Common UI Patterns

### Empty States
Before: "No items"
After: "No prompts yet. Create one to get started!"

Components:
- Clear explanation
- Primary action
- Optional visual/example

### Error Messages  
Before: "Error 404"
After: "We couldn't find that prompt. It may have been deleted."

Structure:
1. What happened
2. Why it happened
3. What to do next

### Confirmation Dialogs
Before: "Are you sure?"
After: "Delete this prompt? This can't be undone."

Best Practices:
- State consequence clearly
- Use specific language
- Make destructive actions red

### Button Copy

| Context | Generic | Improved |
|---------|---------|----------|
| Form | Submit | Save prompt |
| Account | Sign up | Start organizing |
| Trial | Upgrade | Unlock all features |
| Cancel | Cancel | Keep subscription |
| Delete | Delete | Remove permanently |

### Placeholder Text
Before: "Enter text here"
After: "e.g., Write a system prompt for a coding assistant"

Guidelines:
- Show realistic examples
- Demonstrate format
- Inspire without constraining

## Tone Guidelines

### Professional but Friendly
‚ùå "Your request has been processed"
‚úÖ "All set! Your prompt is saved"

### Concise but Complete
‚ùå "This feature allows you to create, edit, and delete prompts"
‚úÖ "Create and manage prompts"

### Encouraging but Not Patronizing
‚ùå "Wow! Great job!"
‚úÖ "First prompt created"

## Checklist

- [ ] Scannable? (2-second grasp)
- [ ] Actionable? (Tells what to do/get)
- [ ] Specific? (Names concrete objects)
- [ ] Concise? (No extra words)
- [ ] Consistent? (Matches surrounding tone)

## 5-Item Rewrite Exercise

1. OLD: "View details" ‚Üí NEW: "See full prompt"
2. OLD: "Settings updated" ‚Üí NEW: "Changes saved"
3. OLD: "Loading..." ‚Üí NEW: "Loading your prompts..."
4. OLD: "No results" ‚Üí NEW: "No matches. Try different keywords"
5. OLD: "Click here" ‚Üí NEW: "Browse all prompts"

Keep rewrites under 5 items for focus.

prompts.title: Dark Mode QA
prompts.body: Checklist: contrast ratios, brand colors, focus states, shadows, borders. Return pass/fail + fixes.

prompts.title: Usability Test Script
prompts.body: Draft 5 usability tasks, success criteria, and post-test questions. Keep under 150 words.

prompts.title: Performance Checklist
prompts.body: List 7 quick wins: image formats, font loading, bundle splitting, caching, prefetching, lazy load, CLS fixes.

prompts.title: Form UX
prompts.body: Improve a form: inline validation, helpful placeholders, clear labels, error recovery, keyboard flow.

prompts.title: Empty States
prompts.body: Design empty state: purpose, friendly copy, next action, example data. Provide 3 variants.

prompts.title: CTA Polish
prompts.body: Rewrite CTA copy for clarity and value. Return 3 options with tone: default, playful, authoritative.

prompts.title: REST Spec Draft
prompts.body: Given a feature, draft endpoints: method, path, request body, response, auth, errors. Keep concise.

prompts.title: Auth Flows
prompts.body: Outline auth flow: login, refresh, revocation. Include token TTL, storage guidance, and error codes.

prompts.title: Webhook Contract
prompts.body: Define webhook payload: event name, schema, signature, retry policy, idempotency guidance.

prompts.title: API Test Matrix Framework
prompts.body:
# API Test Matrix Framework

Generate comprehensive test cases for API endpoints using this systematic approach.

## Test Categories

### 1. Happy Path Tests
Purpose: Verify core functionality works as expected

- Valid authentication token
- Correct request format
- All required fields present
- Expected 200/201 response
- Response schema matches documentation
- Data persistence confirmed

Example:
POST /api/prompts
Headers: Authorization: Bearer <valid_token>
Body: {"title": "Test", "body": "Content"}
Expected: 201 Created with prompt object

### 2. Authentication Failures
Purpose: Ensure proper auth enforcement

Test Cases:
- No token ‚Üí 401 Unauthorized
- Invalid token ‚Üí 401 Unauthorized  
- Wrong permissions ‚Üí 403 Forbidden
- Revoked token ‚Üí 401 Unauthorized

### 3. Validation Errors
Purpose: Test input validation

- Missing required fields ‚Üí 400 Bad Request
- Invalid data types ‚Üí 400
- Field length violations ‚Üí 400
- Invalid enum values ‚Üí 400
- Malformed JSON ‚Üí 400
- SQL injection attempts ‚Üí 400 (sanitized)

Error Response Format:
{
  "error": "validation_error",
  "message": "Title is required",
  "field": "title"
}

### 4. Rate Limiting
Purpose: Verify rate limit enforcement

- Send requests at threshold ‚Üí 200
- Exceed limit ‚Üí 429 Too Many Requests  
- Check X-RateLimit headers
- Verify limit resets after window
- Test per-endpoint vs global limits

### 5. Server Error Handling
Purpose: Ensure graceful degradation

- Database failure ‚Üí 503 Service Unavailable
- External API timeout ‚Üí 504 Gateway Timeout
- Unhandled exception ‚Üí 500 Internal Server Error
- Partial failure ‚Üí 207 Multi-Status

### 6. Idempotency
Purpose: Verify safe retry behavior

- POST same data twice ‚Üí 409 Conflict or idempotency key
- PUT/PATCH same data ‚Üí No state change
- DELETE non-existent ‚Üí 404 or 204
- GET has no side effects

### 7. Edge Cases
Purpose: Test boundary conditions

- Empty strings in optional fields
- Very large payloads
- Unicode and special characters  
- Concurrent requests
- Pagination boundaries

## Test Matrix Template

| Endpoint | Method | Test Case | Input | Status | Body | Notes |
|----------|--------|-----------|-------|--------|------|-------|
| /prompts | POST | Happy path | Valid | 201 | Prompt | - |
| /prompts | POST | No auth | None | 401 | Error | - |
| /prompts | POST | Missing field | No title | 400 | Error | title |
| /prompts | GET | Rate limit | 101st | 429 | Error | 100/min |
| /prompts/:id | DELETE | Not found | Bad ID | 404 | Error | - |

## Automation Tips

- Use test fixtures for consistent data
- Seed database before each suite
- Clean up after each run  
- Mock external dependencies
- Test in isolation
- Parameterize for multiple scenarios

## Prioritization

P0 (Must Pass): Happy path, auth, critical validation
P1 (Should Pass): Rate limiting, errors, edge cases  
P2 (Nice to Have): Idempotency, performance, stress

Output this matrix as a table or JSON for documentation.

prompts.title: Performance Budget
prompts.body: Set latency budget per endpoint. Include p95 goals and caching tips.

prompts.title: Pagination Patterns
prompts.body: Compare page/offset vs cursor vs keyset. Recommend one with rationale and sample request/response.

prompts.title: Error Map
prompts.body: Define error codes/messages for the service. Include user-facing vs internal distinctions.

prompts.title: SDK Brief
prompts.body: Outline minimal SDK: auth, retries, logging, errors. Output function list and signatures.

prompts.title: Schema Diff
prompts.body: Given old vs new schema, list breaking vs non-breaking changes and migration notes.

prompts.title: Rate Limit Policy
prompts.body: Draft rate limit policy: per-endpoint limits, burst rules, headers, error message copy.

prompts.title: Hook Ideas
prompts.body:
Generate 5 compelling hooks for a 60-second explainer video about Prompteka using the Pain‚ÜíRelief framework:

FOR EACH HOOK, INCLUDE:
1. **Opening Line** (7-9 words, attention-grabbing)
2. **Pain Point** (What frustration does it tap into?)
3. **Relief Hint** (Tease the solution without revealing it)
4. **Target Audience** (Who will this resonate with most?)
5. **Emotional Tone** (Frustrated, curious, excited, overwhelmed, etc.)

FOCUS AREAS TO EXPLORE:
- Losing track of favorite AI prompts
- Copying prompts from scattered notes/docs
- Privacy concerns with cloud storage
- Slow workflow switching between apps
- Difficulty organizing growing prompt library

KEEP IT:
- Relatable ("Ever had this happen...?")
- Specific ("500 prompts across 12 different apps")
- Conversational ("Let me show you something")
- Visual (easy to imagine the B-roll)

OUTPUT FORMAT: Numbered list with all 5 elements per hook

prompts.title: Story Beat Outline
prompts.body: 3-act outline: Hook, Problem, Solution, Proof, CTA. Keep to 100 words.

prompts.title: VO Script (60s)
prompts.body: Write a 60s VO script: conversational, concise. Mention local storage + organization.

prompts.title: B-Roll Ideas
prompts.body: List 8 B-roll shots for the app: folders, search, backup, settings, drag/drop, dark mode.

prompts.title: SFX & Music
prompts.body: Recommend music mood and 5 SFX moments (clicks, whoosh, confirm).

prompts.title: Video Hook A/B Testing
prompts.body:
# Video Hook A/B Testing Framework

Create compelling video hooks tailored to different audiences.

## Hook Variant Structure

For each:
1. Opening Line (7-9 words)
2. Pain Point
3. Audience Fit
4. Emotional Tone
5. Predicted Performance

## Example: Prompteka Video

### Hook A: Pain-Agitation
**Opening:** "Tired of losing your best AI prompts?"

**Pain:** Disorganization, scattered notes

**Audience Fit:**
- Makers ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ (daily pain)
- PMs ‚úÖ‚úÖ (moderate)
- Engineers ‚úÖ (less acute)

**Tone:** Frustrated ‚Üí Relieved

**Predicted CTR:**
- Makers: 8.5% (high resonance)
- PMs: 6.2% (aware but less urgent)
- Engineers: 5.1% (have workarounds)

**Rationale:** Makers feel this daily. PMs can delegate. Engineers have scripts.

---

### Hook B: Curiosity-Gap
**Opening:** "Here's how I manage 500+ AI prompts"

**Pain:** Lack of proven solution

**Audience Fit:**
- Makers ‚úÖ‚úÖ
- PMs ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ (seeking best practices)
- Engineers ‚úÖ‚úÖ (technical curiosity)

**Tone:** Curious ‚Üí Intrigued

**Predicted CTR:**
- Makers: 7.1% (interested but less urgent)
- PMs: 9.3% (workflow optimization)
- Engineers: 7.8% (wants to see implementation)

**Rationale:** PMs love "how I" content. Engineers want technical details.

---

### Hook C: Aspirational
**Opening:** "Build a private AI prompt library"

**Pain:** Desire for control, privacy

**Audience Fit:**
- Makers ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ (autonomy)
- PMs ‚úÖ (less hands-on)
- Engineers ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ (privacy + control)

**Tone:** Empowered ‚Üí Motivated

**Predicted CTR:**
- Makers: 8.9% (building appeal)
- PMs: 4.7% (won't implement)
- Engineers: 9.1% (privacy resonates)

**Rationale:** Engineers and makers value self-hosting. PMs less hands-on.

---

## Testing Methodology

### 1. A/B Split by Audience
- Run all 3 simultaneously
- Segment by platform
- 1,000+ views per variant
- Track CTR, watch time, completion

### 2. Sequential
- Hook A for 48 hours
- Analyze top 20% demographics
- Adjust Hook B
- Iterate

### 3. Multivariate
- Hooks √ó Thumbnails
- 9 combinations
- Needs 10K+ views

## Optimization Tips

- Specificity wins: "500+ prompts" > "lots"
- Numbers attract: "3 steps" > "a few"
- Urgency helps: "before you lose" > "eventually"
- Avoid jargon for general audience

## Output Format

HOOK A: [Name]
Opening: [7-9 words]
Audience: Makers ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ | PMs ‚úÖ | Engineers ‚úÖ‚úÖ
CTR: Makers X% | PMs Y% | Engineers Z%
Rationale: [Why different performance]

Test 3 hooks minimum.

prompts.title: 3D UI Token Rendering Specs
prompts.body:
# 3D UI Token Rendering Specifications

## Overview
Create floating 3D representations of Prompteka's core UI elements: prompts, folders, and tags.

## Visual Style

### Lighting Setup
- **Key Light:** Soft, diffused from top-left (45¬∞ angle)
- **Fill Light:** Subtle from bottom-right (prevents harsh shadows)
- **Rim Light:** Gentle backlight for depth separation
- **Ambient:** Low-intensity global illumination

### Color Palette (Pastel)
- **Prompts:** Soft blue (#A8DAFF) with slight gradient to white
- **Folders:** Warm beige (#FFE4B5) with creamy highlights
- **Tags:** Mint green (#B2F5EA) with subtle shimmer

### Material Properties
- **Finish:** Matte with slight satin sheen (not glossy)
- **Roughness:** 0.6-0.7 (soft, approachable)
- **Metalness:** 0 (pure dielectric, no metallic look)
- **Subsurface Scattering:** Minimal (adds warmth)

---

## Token Designs

### Prompt Token (Card)
**Shape:** Rounded rectangle (16:9 aspect ratio)
**Dimensions:** 120mm √ó 68mm √ó 3mm (credit card proportions)
**Details:**
- Embossed text lines (representing content)
- Small circular icon depression (top-left)
- Soft beveled edges (1mm radius)
- Drop shadow (12mm below, 40% opacity, 8mm blur)

**Floating Behavior:**
- Gentle rotation: 5¬∞ tilt on X-axis, 3¬∞ on Y-axis
- Hover height: 20mm above ground plane
- Subtle breathing animation (¬±2mm vertical)

### Folder Token (3D Folder)
**Shape:** Traditional folder with slight modernization
**Dimensions:** 100mm wide √ó 80mm deep √ó 60mm tall (open state)
**Details:**
- Tab at back (20mm exposed)
- Slightly open (15¬∞ angle) showing interior
- Interior color: lighter shade of exterior
- Paper texture on surfaces (subtle)
- Edge thickness: 2mm

**Floating Behavior:**
- Slow rotation: Full 360¬∞ over 20 seconds
- Hover height: 25mm
- Wobble: ¬±1¬∞ on all axes (organic feel)

### Tag Token (Rounded Pill)
**Shape:** Elongated capsule/pill
**Dimensions:** 80mm √ó 30mm √ó 12mm
**Details:**
- Perfectly rounded ends (hemisphere caps)
- Smooth, seamless surface
- Small embossed label text
- No sharp edges

**Floating Behavior:**
- Gentle sway: ¬±10mm horizontal drift (8-second loop)
- Hover height: 15mm
- Slow spin: 180¬∞ rotation over 12 seconds

---

## Composition & Arrangement

### Scene Layout
**Camera:** Isometric view (35mm equivalent, slight wide angle)
**Token Placement:**
- Prompt token: Center-left, facing viewer
- Folder token: Right side, slightly back
- Tag token: Front-right, lower position

**Depth Staging:**
- Near: Tag (closest to camera)
- Mid: Prompt (main focus)
- Far: Folder (background element)

**Spacing:** 40-60mm between tokens (avoid overlap)

### Background
- **Type:** Gradient backdrop (not solid)
- **Colors:** Very light blue-gray (#F0F4F8) to white
- **Vignette:** Subtle darkening at edges (10% opacity)
- **Ground Plane:** Infinite, reflects tokens (20% opacity, blurred)

---

## Technical Specifications

### Rendering Settings
- **Resolution:** 4K (3840√ó2160) minimum
- **Anti-Aliasing:** 8x MSAA or equivalent TAA
- **Ray Tracing:** Enabled for accurate shadows/reflections
- **Samples:** 512+ for final render (no noise)
- **Color Space:** sRGB (for web) or Display P3 (for print)

### File Formats
- **Hero Image:** PNG (lossless, alpha channel)
- **Thumbnail:** JPG (85% quality, 1920√ó1080)
- **Motion Version:** MP4 (H.264, 30fps, 10 seconds loop)

### Animation Parameters (if applicable)
- **Duration:** 10-second seamless loop
- **Easing:** Ease-in-out (no abrupt movements)
- **Frame Rate:** 30fps (smooth, not jarring)

---

## Usage Context
- **Marketing:** Website hero, social media graphics
- **Documentation:** Feature explainers, UI guides
- **App:** Onboarding illustrations, empty states

**Deliverables:**
1. Static render (PNG, 4K)
2. Animated loop (MP4, 1080p)
3. Individual token renders (isolated, transparent BG)

prompts.title: Customer Churn Analysis Framework
prompts.body:
# Customer Churn Analysis & Retention Framework

## Survey Questions (5 Core)

### 1. Primary Reason for Cancellation
"What's the main reason you're considering canceling?"

**Options:**
- [ ] Too expensive / not enough value
- [ ] Missing features I need
- [ ] Found a better alternative
- [ ] Technical issues / bugs
- [ ] Rarely use it anymore
- [ ] Privacy / security concerns
- [ ] Other: _______________

**Follow-up:** "Can you tell us more about [selected reason]?"

### 2. Feature Gap Analysis
"Which features would make you reconsider?"

**Options (multi-select):**
- [ ] Cloud sync across devices
- [ ] Team collaboration
- [ ] API access
- [ ] Mobile app
- [ ] Advanced search/filters
- [ ] Import from [competitor]
- [ ] Other: _______________

### 3. Usage Pattern
"How often did you use Prompteka in the last month?"

- [ ] Daily
- [ ] Weekly  
- [ ] Monthly
- [ ] Rarely / Never

**Insight:** Correlate usage frequency with churn likelihood

### 4. Competitive Landscape
"If you're switching, which tool are you moving to?"

- [ ] [Competitor A]
- [ ] [Competitor B]
- [ ] Custom solution / scripts
- [ ] Going back to notes/docs
- [ ] Not using a prompt manager
- [ ] Other: _______________

**Follow-up:** "What does [that tool] offer that we don't?"

### 5. NPS Recovery
"On a scale of 0-10, how likely would you recommend Prompteka to a colleague?"

**Score: [ ]**

**If 0-6 (Detractors):**
"What would it take to change your score to a 9 or 10?"

---

## Save Offers (3 Tiers)

### Offer 1: Discount (Price-Sensitive Users)
**Trigger:** Selected "Too expensive"

**Offer:**
"We'd hate to lose you. Here's 40% off for the next 3 months‚Äîno commitment required."

**Button:** "Apply discount & stay"

**Expected Save Rate:** 35-45%

---

### Offer 2: Feature Preview (Feature-Gapped Users)
**Trigger:** Selected "Missing features" + identified specific needs

**Offer:**
"Good news! [Feature X] is launching next month. Want early access?"

**Button:** "Get early access"

**Expected Save Rate:** 25-35%

---

### Offer 3: Pause Option (Low-Usage Users)
**Trigger:** Selected "Rarely use" or usage < 2x/month

**Offer:**
"Need a break? Pause your subscription for up to 3 months. Your data stays safe, no charge."

**Button:** "Pause subscription"

**Expected Save Rate:** 20-30%

---

## Implementation Flow

1. **Trigger:** User clicks "Cancel subscription"
2. **Survey:** Show 5 questions (required)
3. **Save Offer:** Based on responses, show most relevant offer
4. **Outcome Tracking:**
   - Stayed (with/without offer)
   - Paused
   - Canceled
   - Reason categorization

## Key Metrics to Track

- **Churn Rate:** (Cancellations / Active Users) √ó 100
- **Save Rate:** (Retained / Cancellation Attempts) √ó 100
- **Reason Distribution:** % per reason category
- **Offer Effectiveness:** Save rate per offer type
- **Usage Correlation:** Churn rate by usage tier

## Analysis Questions

**Weekly Review:**
- Which churn reason is growing fastest?
- Are save offers performing better/worse?
- Any patterns in churned user profiles?

**Monthly Deep Dive:**
- Cohort analysis: Does churn stabilize after X months?
- Feature requests from churned users
- Competitor movement trends

---

**Priority:** Always address the top churn reason first. One major fix beats three minor improvements.

prompts.title: Landing Headline
prompts.body:
Write 5 landing page headlines for Prompteka following conversion-optimized best practices:

GUIDELINES:
- **Length:** 6-12 words (scannable, punchy)
- **Tone:** Clear and benefit-driven, not clever or cute
- **Focus:** What users GET, not what the product IS
- **Avoid:** Buzzwords like "revolutionize", "game-changing", "innovative"

HEADLINE FORMATS TO TRY:
1. **Problem ‚Üí Solution:** "Tired of [pain]? [Benefit] with Prompteka"
2. **Outcome Statement:** "[Desired result] in [timeframe/method]"
3. **How Statement:** "How [target audience] [achieve goal]"
4. **Question Hook:** "[Pain point question]? There's a better way"
5. **Benefit-First:** "[Main benefit] without [common drawback]"

KEY SELLING POINTS TO EMPHASIZE:
- All prompts stored locally (privacy)
- Instant search across your entire library
- Organized with folders, colors, emojis
- Quick access via global shortcut (Cmd+Shift+P)
- No subscriptions or cloud dependencies

For each headline, include a 1-sentence subheading that adds context without being redundant.

EXAMPLE OUTPUT:
**Headline:** "Your AI prompts, organized and private"
**Subhead:** "Store unlimited prompts locally with instant search and zero cloud sync."

prompts.title: A/B Hero Copy Testing
prompts.body:
# A/B Hero Copy Testing Framework

Create two distinct hero copy variants optimized for different value propositions.

## Variant A: Privacy-First

### Headline
"Your AI Prompts, Private and Organized"

### Subhead
"Store unlimited prompts locally with zero cloud sync. Fast search, smart folders, complete privacy."

### CTA Primary
"Download for Mac"

### CTA Secondary  
"See how it works"

### Value Props (3 bullets)
- üîí 100% local storage‚Äîyour data never leaves your Mac
- ‚ö° Lightning-fast search across all prompts
- üìÅ Organize with folders, tags, and emoji icons

### Target Audience
- Privacy-conscious users
- Enterprise users with data policies
- Security researchers
- Users burned by cloud breaches

### Predicted Performance
- **Click-Through:** 8.2% (high intent, specific pain point)
- **Conversion:** 12% (motivated, clear need)
- **Objections:** "Does it have cloud backup?" (No, but export)

---

## Variant B: Speed-First

### Headline
"Find Any AI Prompt in Milliseconds"

### Subhead
"Instant full-text search. Keyboard shortcuts. Zero cloud lag. Built for power users."

### CTA Primary
"Start organizing now"

### CTA Secondary
"Watch demo"

### Value Props (3 bullets)
- ‚ö° Search 1,000+ prompts instantly
- ‚å®Ô∏è Global shortcut (Cmd+Shift+P) from anywhere
- üöÄ No loading, no syncing, just fast

### Target Audience
- Power users
- Developers with large prompt libraries
- Users frustrated with slow cloud apps
- Keyboard-first workflows

### Predicted Performance
- **Click-Through:** 7.8% (appeals to efficiency)
- **Conversion:** 14% (clear workflow improvement)
- **Objections:** "How much does it cost?" (One-time purchase)

---

## Testing Methodology

### 1. Split Test Setup
- 50/50 traffic split
- Minimum 2,000 visitors per variant
- Run for 7 days minimum
- Track: CTR, scroll depth, time on page, conversion

### 2. Segmentation Analysis
Analyze performance by:
- **Traffic Source:** Direct, organic, social, ads
- **Device:** Desktop vs mobile
- **Geography:** US, EU, Asia
- **Behavior:** New vs returning visitors

### 3. Qualitative Feedback
- **Surveys:** "What made you click?" (post-CTA)
- **Session Recordings:** Watch 50 sessions per variant
- **Heatmaps:** Click patterns, scroll depth

## Key Metrics

| Metric | Variant A (Privacy) | Variant B (Speed) |
|--------|---------------------|-------------------|
| CTR | 8.2% | 7.8% |
| Conversion | 12% | 14% |
| Bounce Rate | 32% | 28% |
| Time on Page | 1:24 | 1:42 |

## Decision Framework

**Choose Privacy-First (A) if:**
- High-value enterprise leads
- Security-focused audience
- Competitive landscape emphasizes privacy

**Choose Speed-First (B) if:**
- Power user audience (devs, PMs)
- Fast is a key differentiator
- Users cite "slow apps" as pain point

## Iteration Plan

After initial test:
1. **Winner takes 80%** traffic
2. Test new variant against winner (20% traffic)
3. Iterate on losing elements (headline, CTA, props)
4. Repeat monthly

---

## Copy Guidelines

### Headlines (6-10 words)
- Lead with primary benefit
- Avoid jargon/buzzwords
- Make promise specific

### Subheads (12-18 words)
- Support headline with "how"
- Add secondary benefits
- Create urgency/FOMO subtly

### CTAs (2-3 words)
- Action verb + benefit
- Not: "Learn More" / "Get Started"
- Yes: "Download Now" / "Start Free Trial"

Test both variants. Data wins over opinions.

prompts.title: Testimonials

prompts.title: Competitive Analysis Framework
prompts.body:
# Competitive Analysis Framework

## Competitor Matrix

### Competitor 1: [Cloud Prompt Manager A]
**Positioning:** Team collaboration, cloud-first

**Strengths:**
- Real-time sync across devices
- Team sharing and permissions
- Version history
- Web-based (no install)
- Integrations with popular AI tools

**Weaknesses:**
- Monthly subscription ($15/mo)
- Privacy concerns (data on servers)
- Slower with large libraries (1000+ prompts)
- Requires internet connection
- Limited offline functionality

**Gaps Prompteka Fills:**
- No subscription (one-time purchase)
- 100% local storage (privacy)
- Fast with any library size
- Works offline always
- Simple, focused UX (no team bloat)

---

### Competitor 2: [Notion/Obsidian Extensions]
**Positioning:** DIY, note-taking add-ons

**Strengths:**
- Free (if you already use the tool)
- Flexible (markdown-based)
- Existing user base
- Extensible with plugins

**Weaknesses:**
- Not purpose-built for prompts
- Setup friction (install, configure)
- No prompt-specific features (emoji icons, tags, preview modes)
- Cluttered UX (designed for notes, not prompts)
- Slow search in large databases

**Gaps Prompteka Fills:**
- Purpose-built for AI prompts
- Zero setup (works immediately)
- Prompt-specific features (preview, tags, emojis)
- Clean, focused UX
- Faster search

---

### Competitor 3: [GitHub Gists / Plain Files]
**Positioning:** Free, developer-friendly

**Strengths:**
- Free
- Version control (Git)
- Accessible everywhere (web, CLI)
- Developer-friendly
- Backup inherent (Git)

**Weaknesses:**
- Public by default (privacy risk if not careful)
- No UX (just text files)
- No search across gists
- No organization (folders, tags)
- Cumbersome workflow (create, copy, paste)

**Gaps Prompteka Fills:**
- Beautiful, native UX
- Private by default
- Instant search
- Rich organization (folders, tags, colors)
- One-click copy

---

### Competitor 4: [IDE Snippets]
**Positioning:** Integrated into dev environment

**Strengths:**
- Already in workflow
- Fast access (keyboard shortcuts)
- Free (built into IDE)
- Syntax highlighting

**Weaknesses:**
- IDE-specific (not accessible outside)
- Limited to code snippets (not long prompts)
- No preview modes (markdown, HTML)
- No cross-IDE sync
- Poor for non-code prompts

**Gaps Prompteka Fills:**
- Universal (works outside IDE)
- Handles long-form prompts
- Rich preview modes
- Accessible from any app
- Not just for code

---

### Competitor 5: [Copy-Paste from Docs/Sheets]
**Positioning:** Ad-hoc, no dedicated tool

**Strengths:**
- Free
- Familiar (everyone knows Docs)
- Shareable (links)
- Collaborative

**Weaknesses:**
- Not searchable across docs
- No tagging or organization
- Slow (scroll, find, copy)
- Clunky for frequent use
- No offline access (Docs)

**Gaps Prompteka Fills:**
- Fast search
- Rich organization
- One-click copy
- Offline-first
- Purpose-built UX

---

## Summary: Prompteka's Unique Position

**vs Cloud Tools:** Privacy + Speed + No subscription
**vs DIY Solutions:** Purpose-built + Beautiful UX + Zero setup
**vs Free Options:** Organized + Fast search + Professional tool

## Messaging Strategy

**Don't say:** "We're better than X"

**Do say:**
- "If you care about privacy, use Prompteka instead of [Cloud Tool]"
- "If you're tired of [DIY approach], Prompteka just works"
- "If you need a professional tool, not a hack, choose Prompteka"

---

## Competitive Monitoring

**Monthly Check:**
- New features from competitors
- Pricing changes
- User reviews (what do users love/hate?)
- Market shifts (new entrants)

**Respond To:**
- Major feature gaps (if widely requested)
- Pricing pressure (if market shifts)
- New use cases (if addressable)

**Ignore:**
- Enterprise features we don't serve
- Team collaboration (out of scope)
- AI integrations (keep focused)
